text:
Vessel and experimental equipment specifications

This study was conducted on a low-speed, two-stroke, in-line six-cylinder diesel engine used as the main propulsion system of a 9,196-ton class passenger vessel for international voyages. The engine delivers an output of 6,618 kW at a maximum speed of 146 RPM and uses Bunker A fuel, which is a blend of 70% diesel and 30% heavy fuel oil. The experimental vessel departed from its home port, Mokpo, Republic of Korea, and sailed in coastal waters. Data were collected in various operational modes during the navigation. Table 1 lists the detailed specifications of the vessel and engine used in the experiments.

During vessel operation, the actual CO2, CO, and NOX emission data were collected from the exhaust gases emitted by the main propulsion engine. The engine operating data were obtained from the alarm monitoring system (AMS), which comprehensively manages and monitors the operational data of the vessel’s machinery. The AMS collects and monitors the real-time machinery status through various sensors installed during ship construction, enabling the verification of each piece of machinery’s operating conditions and functional status. The OBS-ONE-GS12 HDV model (Horiba Ltd., Kyoto, Japan) was used to measure gas emissions, and continuous measurements were conducted for the device’s maximum operational duration (4 h) during the voyage. The measurement device was calibrated before and after the measurement, and because the exhaust gas from the main propulsion engine of the vessel contained significantly more particulate matter than that from road mobiles, the internal filter was replaced every 4 h to maintain measurement reliability. The emission measurement method was designed following the IMO Marine Environment Protection Committee (MEPC) guidelines. CO2 and CO were measured using a nondispersive infrared (NDIR) method, and NOX was measured via chemiluminescence detection (CLD)25. The detailed specifications of portable emission measurement system (PEMS) are provided in Table 2.

AMS and PEMS data were synchronized during acquisition, a residual latency between the two systems cannot be entirely excluded because of sensor response and signal processing delays in the PEMS. In this study, the latency was considered negligible relative to the 0.1 Hz sampling interval; therefore, no explicit alignment correction was applied. However, for broader development, quantifying the time offset between AMS and PEMS and adjusting the window alignment accordingly is recommended to ensure robust training and real time applicability.

Figure 1 shows a schematic of the data acquisition process. Data were collected over the entire operational sections of the vessel, including arrival and departure. The collected data include engine operating conditions and actual measured emission data. The engine operation data comprise 104 variables, including the RPM, torque, power, exhaust gas temperature for each cylinder, and maximum combustion pressure. These were compiled with the CO2, CO, and NOX emission data into a database. The data sample rate of the AMS was set to 0.1 Hz, resulting in 7,147 samples. Among them, 3389 samples were used as the training set, and the remaining 3758 samples were allocated to the test set for the prediction model.

The modeling was conducted in a controlled computing environment to ensure efficient training of the proposed deep learning models, reproducibility, and to clearly define the constraints on scalability. The hardware configuration included an Intel Core i9-10900KF CPU and 32 GB of RAM. The software environment consisted of Python version 3.9.13 running on window 10 Pro 64-bit. Detailed hardware and software specifications are summarized in Table 3.

Prediction modeling with TSF-Transformer and XGBoost

Figure 2 shows a flowchart for developing the stacking emission prediction model based on TSF-Transformer and XGBoost. The entire dataset was divided into training (3389 rows) and test (3758 rows) samples, with each dataset including different operational modes—from dead slow to full navigation. Nonnumerical fields and missing values were removed from the raw data to minimize errors during model training, and min–max scaling was applied to improve the learning stability and convergence speed. LASSO-based feature selection was performed to identify key input features that affect the target variables, and the final input dataset was constructed based on the selected features. Furthermore, the hyperparameters for both the TSF-Transformer and XGBoost were optimized through K-Fold cross-validation (k = 5) using the Optuna framework. Based on the obtained results, a stacking-structured prediction model was developed, and its performance was evaluated using the test dataset.

Figure 3 shows the structure of the proposed stacking prediction model. Input features selected using LASSO are structured into time-series sequences and fed into the encoder block of the TSF-Transformer, which captures the temporal dependencies using multi-head attention and feedforward layers. Simultaneously, the same features are used to train an XGBoost regression model, and each model performs an initial prediction independently. Subsequently, the predictions from the Transformer and XGBoost models and their first-order differences are combined to form the meta input, which is then fed into the final XGBoost-based meta-model to produce the final prediction. This ensemble structure compensates for the weaknesses of individual models while leveraging their complementary strengths, thereby improving both prediction performance and robustness.

Table 4 lists the optimal combination of hyperparameters for the proposed model. To maximize the prediction performance of the proposed model, the Optuna framework was used to perform hyperparameter optimization using a Bayesian optimizer based on the tree-structured Parzen estimator (TPE). For each hyperparameter combination, five-fold cross-validation was performed. In each fold, the TSF-Transformer was first trained, followed by the construction of meta-inputs using its output along with the XGBoost predictions and their first-order differences. Based on these inputs, the final metal model was trained. During validation, the objective function of Optuna was defined to minimize the RMSE. Because CO2, CO, and NOX have distinct time-series characteristics, scales, and combinations of influential variables, optimal hyperparameter tuning was performed separately for each target. The final optimized combination of hyperparameters improved the prediction accuracy while preventing overfitting in each prediction model, providing a basis for designing the optimal structure for each target. The training time for each model was also recorded to indicate the computational demand of the proposed approach. Specifically, the training required 108.21 s for the CO2 model, 40.79 s for the CO model, and 24.24 s for the NOX model. These results confirm that, even with a training dataset of 3389 samples and the adopted hyperparameter configurations, the training process can be completed efficiently within a relatively short time on the specified hardware environment.

Training variables for each emission’s prediction model

LASSO feature selection was employed to identify the most influential input variables for prediction each pollutants. The final sets of selected features are summarized in Tables 5, 6 and 7. For the CO2 emission prediction model, a total 50 variables were selected, including fuel consumption and main engine air cooler cooling water outlet temperature. For the CO prediction model, 15 variables were used, including main engine load, whereas 27 variables were applied for the NOX prediction model. All input data, excluding the emission measurements, were derived from vessel operation information acquired through the alarm monitoring system at a sampling frequency of 0.1 Hz.

For CO emissions, previous studies (Will et al., 2007; Yan et al., 2021) have reported that the intake pressure of diesel engines significantly affects CO formation26,27. Based on this evidence, adding combustion-specific variables was considered, namely the average maximum cylinder pressure and the average cylinder compression pressure, in addition to the LASSO-selected features. However, the experimental results revealed that including these combustion-specific variables did not improve model performance; instead, the prediction accuracy deteriorated in terms quantitative indicators such as MAE and RMSE. This suggests that the additional features may have introduced noise or redundancy that hindered effective learning. Consequently, these variables were excluded from the final model. Nevertheless, it is anticipated that incorporating other combustion-specific parameters not included in this study—such as fuel injection timing and injection pressure—could further enhance the accuracy and robustness of CO emission prediction in future work.

The influence of the selected variables differed depending on the target pollutant. Some variables directly contributed to increasing emissions (LASSO, +), whereas others acted as suppressing factors(LASSO, -). Notably, the experimental vessel was equipped with a controllable pitch propeller (CPP), allowing the propeller angle to be adjusted for propulsion. Variances in the CPP pitch were found to affect emission formation; an increase in propeller pitch tended to reduce CO2 and NOX emissions, but conversely led to an increase in CO emissions. This indicates that CPP dynamics exert a nonlinear influence on combustion conditions and exhaust gas formation. Accordingly, the same input variable can exert opposite effects depending on the emission species, highlighting the limitation of using a single independent variable sets and optimization procedures for each pollutant, which substantially improved the overall predictive performance of the proposed model.

Bottom–up emission prediction approach

We compared the performance of the proposed model with that of the bottom–up approach reported by the IMO and EEA, which is commonly used to calculate vessel emissions. The bottom–up method estimates fuel consumption based on vessel characteristics and operational data to calculate emissions. It exhibits higher accuracy than the top–down approach, which relies solely on fuel sales data28,29,30.

To calculate fuel consumption, information about the engine load and power from vessel activity data is essential. Based on the load data obtained from the AMS, the fuel consumption was calculated using the method proposed by the IMO. The specific fuel oil consumption (SFOC) according to the load can be expressed as follows:

$$\:{SFOC}_{load}={SFOC}_{baseline}\times\:\left(0.4555\times\:{load}^{2}-0.71\times\:load+1.28\right),$$

(1)

where SFOCload ​is the SFOC under the engine load (g/kWh), and SFOCbaseline is the SFOC as fuel (g/kWh). In this study, Burker A was used as fuel in the slow-speed engine. It was consumed at 175 g/kWh31.

Using the SFOCload calculated in Eq. (1) and the engine power data, the fuel consumption can be estimated as follows:

$$\:{q}_{f}={SFOC}_{load}\times\:P,$$

(2)

where qf is the fuel consumption (g), and P is the engine power (kW).

According to the IMO and EEA, CO2 and CO emissions can be calculated by multiplying the fuel consumption by the emission factor (EF), as expressed in Eq. (3). However, the EEA calculates NOX emissions by multiplying the fuel consumption by EF, whereas the IMO calculates using Eq. (4). The EF values for various pollutants are listed in Table 8. Although the IMO does not explicitly define Bunker A as s separate fuel category, it is generally considered as a residual fuel oil with properties similar to low-sulphur heavy fuel oil. Accordingly, the emission factors were selected based on the default carbon content and fuel-specific coefficient reported in the Fourth IMO GHG Study (2020) and the IMO NOX Technical Code (2008), which are applicable to residual marine fuel.

$$\:{EM}_{i}=FC\times\:{EF}_{i},$$

(3)

where EM is the emission quantity (g), and i indicates the emission type.

$$\:{EM}_{NOx}={EF}_{NOx}\times\:\frac{{SFOC}_{base}}{{SFOC}_{CG}}\times\:P,$$

(4)

where EFNOx is the emission factor for NOx, and SFOCCG is the SFOC value proposed by Cooper and Gustanffson (2004)32,33.

The prediction performance of the proposed model was evaluated by comparing the emissions estimated using the proposed model and the bottom–up methods proposed by the IMO and EEA.

Figure 4 shows the correlation between SFOC and load according to the engine RPM. The correlation follows a cubic relationship or the propeller law34. Typically, for vessels with medium- to large-scale low-speed engines, the engine is directly connected to the propeller without a reduction gear. Here, the SFOC was higher under low-speed, low-load conditions during maneuvering and lower under high-speed, high-load conditions during sailing. This result can be attributed to the reduced thermal efficiency under low engine loads due to the lower fuel injection pressure, suboptimal fuel injection timing, and insufficient scavenging air for combustion35. However, as shown in the yellow-shaded area of Figure 4(a), some data deviate from the general trend, which can be attributed to the fact that the experimental vessel was equipped with a CPP rather than a fixed-pitch propeller (FPP) for propulsion. CPPs allow thrust adjustment by varying the propeller pitch while maintaining constant engine RPM. The variations in the propeller pitch in those sections result in nonlinear fuel consumption patterns. Excluding such sections, Figure 4(b) shows a pattern consistent with the propeller law typically observed for FPPs. In this study, the entire operational dataset, including the sections affected by pitch variations, was used for training to ensure generalized performance under diverse operating conditions. However, the 100–120 RPM range is classified as a critical RPM zone due to structural resonance issues in the engine. In actual operations, it is avoided to prevent mechanical damage to the engine. In this range, the sudden increase in fuel injection rate can cause a transient rise in exhaust gas pressure, potentially leading to measurement errors in the PEMS. In addition, non-physical or unrealistic values from the AMS and PEMS (e.g., abnormal emission spikes, sensor malfunctions) were identified through cross-checking with engineering and temporal continuity, and subsequently removed. This screening process ensured that only physically meaningful and consistent data were used for model training.

Figure 5 shows the operational activity of the experimental vessel during the measurements. In certain sections, changes in the propeller pitch resulted in differences in the load and speed despite the constant RPM. These sections correspond to the deviations from the trend in Figure 4(a). These results indicate that, unlike FPPs, CPPs require additional variables for accurate emission calculations. Therefore, we included such sections in the training data and constructed the prediction model accordingly. In the sections not affected by the CPP, pitch, load, and speed varied in a similar pattern with respect to the RPM. Although minor differences were observed, the trend is similar to that of FPPs. Therefore, the proposed prediction model based on CPPs can exhibit comparable performance when applied to vessels with FPPs. This will be verified in future studies by collecting vessel operation and emission data without variations in the propeller pitch.

In addition, a SHAP-based sensitivity analysis was conducted to compare the CPP-affected segments with non-affected ones. The results show that the contribution of the propeller pitch variable exhibited no significant change between the two segments, indicating that the model did not rely heavily on pitch variation for prediction (see Supplementary Fig. S1–S3). This suggests that the proposed model retains generalizability and can adapt to vessels equipped with FPP without retraining.

The prediction results obtained using the proposed hybrid prediction model were compared with the emissions estimated using the conventional bottom–up approaches reported by IMO and EEA and those measured using a PEMS. Figures 6(a)–(c) compare the measured and predicted emissions for each pollutant. The magnified areas in the figures highlight representative segments where the differences in model performance are pronounced. Overall, the proposed model outperformed the bottom–up methods, especially under dynamic conditions.

As shown in Figure 6(a), the CO2 emissions estimated by the IMO and EEA approaches are identical because the same EF and equation are used in both cases. Both methods significantly underestimated CO2 emissions compared to the measured values, especially under high-load conditions. In contrast, the proposed model estimated CO2 emissions close to the measured values not only under high-load conditions but also during transient events, such as rapid load increases and decreases caused by large changes in RPM.

Figure 6(b) compares the predicted and measured CO emissions. CO emissions vary significantly compared with CO2 and NOX emissions. The IMO and EEA methods showed similar general trends but significantly underestimated the emissions, especially under high-load conditions. In contrast, the proposed model tends to overestimate CO emissions at high load, despite the hyperparameter being optimized. This suggests that the features selected by LASSO may not fully represent combustion processes under steady high-load conditions. Moreover, the relatively narrow yet highly fluctuating distribution of CO may have introduced instability in pattern learning. Additional factors such as sensor noise and limited sample converge at critical operating points could also have contributed to these deviations. Therefore, future work should consider preprocessing techniques (e.g., noise reduction) and incorporating combustion-specific variable to address these limitations. And multi-task learning that leverage the correlation among CO, CO2 and NOX emissions may improve robustness.

The proposed model accurately captured the emission trend, except in certain sections where a sharp emission spike was observed. These results demonstrate that the proposed model exhibits improved prediction performance.

Figure 6(c) shows the predicted and measured NOX emissions. The IMO bottom–up approach underestimated the emissions relative to the measured values, whereas the EEA method overestimated them. The EEA values more significantly deviated from the measured values than the IMO values, which can be attributed to the fact that the IMO method uses EFs that depend on the engine RPM, whereas the EEA method uses constant EFs. The proposed model, which predicts emissions based on actual engine operating data, accurately predicted the emission trends and achieved minimal deviation from the measured emissions.

Figure 7 shows the regression analysis results of the CO2, CO, and NOX emissions predicted using the proposed model with respect to the measured values. A residual plot is provided for each subplot to evaluate the validity of the regression model. The adjusted R² and slope for Figure 7(a) are 0.9935 and 0.9627, respectively, indicating that the predicted and measured CO2 emissions are in good agreement. The residuals are evenly distributed around zero, indicating no heteroscedasticity and supporting the validity of the regression model.

As shown in Figure 7(b), CO emissions had relatively larger residuals than the other pollutants. The adjusted R2 value was 0.6324, and the slope was 0.7660, indicating moderate prediction accuracy. The larger residuals can be attributed to the inherently high variations in the measured CO emission data. In future studies, more standardized CO data should be collected to retrain the model and improve its robustness. While CO showed comparatively larger residuals, this may also reflect feature insufficiency with respect to combustion-specific mechanisms. Prior studies indicate that injection timing and resulting in-cylinder pressure/heat-release phasing markedly influence incomplete oxidation products such as CO in compression-ignition engines4,36. Accordingly, future work will instrument combustion-specific variables (e.g., fuel injection timing, valve event timing) and retrain the model to better capture CO formation dynamics under diverse operating regimes.

As shown in Figure 7(c), although some data points deviate from the main trend, the adjusted R2 and slope are 0.9716 and 0.9623, respectively, indicating excellent prediction of NOX emissions by the proposed model using only the engine data. Except for a few outliers, the residuals were uniformly distributed, confirming that NOX emissions can be accurately estimated using only engine operation data.

Figure 8 shows the prediction and estimation error distributions of the proposed model and conventional bottom-up approaches (IMO and EEA) for each pollutant. In the histograms, the right- and left-skewed distributions indicate underestimation and overestimation, respectively. For all pollutants, the bottom–up approaches exhibited skewed error distributions, showing either underestimation or overestimation. In contrast, the proposed model exhibited approximately normal error distributions centered around zero, indicating better fit and accuracy.

Figure 8(a) presents the error distribution of CO2 emission prediction. The proposed TSF-Transformer model shows that most errors are concentrated near zero, indicating closer agreement with the actual emissions compared to the IMO and EEA methods. While the IMO and EEA approached consistently underestimate emissions with peaks around − 60 to − 80, the proposed model exhibits a higher frequency in the − 20 to 0 range, reflecting better reproduction for actual values under high-load conditions. This characteristic is particularly advantageous for maritime applications, as vessel spend most of their operation time in high-load sailing segments where accurate emission estimation is critical. Nevertheless, a residual bias toward underestimation remains in the distribution tails. Future works should focus on refining feature selection and applying advanced preprocessing techniques to reduce this bias. Moreover, separating stable segments from highly variable transient segments and analyzing feature sensitivity may future reduce variance in the error distribution and narrow the confidence interval of emission estimates.

For CO emissions (Figure 8(b)), despite the high variability of the measured data, the proposed model shows that errors are concentrated around zero. While the IMO and EEA approaches predominantly underestimate emissions, the proposed model exhibits a slight tendency toward overestimation, but with substantially smaller errors overall. Similar to CO2, underestimation is observed in the low-load region, whereas overestimation appears in the high-load region. To mitigate these issues, not only should feature selection be further refined, but combustion-specific variables such as fuel injection timing and pressure should also be incorporated. In addition, applying preprocessing techniques such as noise reduction—within the range that preserves the reliability of highly variable measured data—may enhance the model’s pattern recognition and learning effectiveness.

For NOX emissions (Figure 8(c)), the IMO method tends to underestimate while the EEA method tends to overestimate, whereas the proposed model demonstrate an error distribution centered closer to zero. The error range is also much narrower than those of the bottom-up approaches, highlighting the substantial improvement in prediction accuracy.

Figures 9(a)–(c) show the distribution of the CO2, CO, and NOX prediction errors with respect to the engine operating conditions, particularly the RPM and torque, which are key indicators of engine variability. The left and right plots in each subplot project the error distributions with respect to the RPM and torque, respectively. In all subplots, the shaded blue area represents the ± 5% error band relative to the maximum measured emission. The percentage of predictions within this band is also indicated.

As shown in Figure 9(a), 85.63% of the predictions fall within the ± 5% band, indicating consistently strong performance across most operating condition. Lager deviation appear mainly at low-RPM and torque segments, which are characterized by transient behavior and reduced engine stability. Because the test set is dominated by high-load operation, the improved accuracy in those segments makes the approach particularly suitable for estimating real-world CO2 emissions. Reducing the residual bias at low-load will likely require segment-specific rather than a single global model.

In contrast, CO remains the most challenging pollutant. Only 18.03% of prediction lie within ± 5%, and the error frequency increases toward high-RPM and torque where combustion changes rapidly. Two factors appear to limit performance. First, feature sufficiency: the LASSO-selected variables capture steady-state trends but under-represent combustion dynamics that strongly affect CO (e.g., fuel injection timing, pressure, air-fuel ratio indicators). Second, measurement scale and noise: although the PEMS was calibrated with a 4.74% CO span gas, voyage measurement were typically 0.01–0.03%. Operating far below the calibration span increase relative noise and makes short sparks hard to learn. To address these issues, we plan to (ⅰ) incorporate combustion-specific variables obtainable from the engine control/monitoring system; (ⅱ) adopt noise-aware preprocessing, e.g., stationary wavelet denoising to suppress isolated spikes while preserving step changes; (ⅲ) rebalance training with load-aware sampling so that low- and high-load segments are adequately represented; and (ⅳ) use robust/heteroscedastic objectives and a two branch architecture that learns separate experts for low- and high-load regimes with a simple load-based gate. In parallel, we will recalibrate the analyzer with lower-range span gas aligned to the observed concentration range to reduce instrument noise and improve label fidelity. These targeted steps are expected to improve CO robustness beyond what can be achieved by hyperparameter tuning alone.

For NOx (Figure 9(c)), 53.72% of the predictions are within the ± 5% range. Although the proposed model exhibited high performance under most operating conditions, larger deviations can occur under extremely high or low engine loads due to the nonlinear nature of NOX formation or insufficient training data for such edge cases.

The results confirm that the proposed data-driven approach substantially improve CO2 and NOx estimates under representative operating conditions, while CO accuracy remains limited by feature sufficiency and measurement scaling. Rather than attributing CO underperformance solely to “inherent variability”, we identify concrete, testable remedies—combustion-aware features, load-aware modeling, robust losses, wavelet-based denoising, and calibration range matching—that we will implement next to close the gap.

Table 9 presents the quantitative evaluation of the proposed model compared with conventional emission estimation methods. The comparison indicators are the coefficient of determination (R2), adjusted R2, RMSE, MAE, and MAPE.

For CO2, all methods, including the proposed model, exhibited high R2 values, ranging from 0.9935 to 0.9947. However, the proposed model exhibited significantly lower RMSE (43.52) and MAE (35.75) than the bottom–up approaches proposed by IMO and EEA (RMSE = 65.69 and MAE = 59.59). Compared with the conventional bottom–up approaches, the RMSE of the proposed model was improved by approximately 34%, and the MAE was improved by approximately 40%, indicating that the proposed model not only maintains a high correlation but also exhibits improved accuracy in absolute terms.

For CO, the proposed model exhibited an R2 of 0.6324 and an RMSE of only 0.94, which are lower than those of the IMO and EEA methods 0.7339 and 1.72, 1.78, respectively), indicating that the proposed model significantly outperforms the conventional approaches. In addition, the MAE of the proposed model (0.78) was significantly lower than that of the EEA method (1.61), indicating better generalizability of the proposed model despite significant variations in CO emissions. Compared with the EEA method, which showed a larger discrepancy than the IMO approach, the RMSE and MAE of the proposed model improved by approximately 45% and 47%, respectively.

For NOX, the proposed model exhibited an R2 of 0.9716, which is slightly lower than that of the conventional bottom–up approach method; however, its RMSE (1.60) is much lower than that of the IMO and EEA methods (2.71 and 5.08, respectively), indicating a more balanced performance. In addition, with an MAE of 1.27, the proposed model demonstrated more than a 40% improvement in RMSE and 48% improvement in MAE compared with the IMO method, which estimates emissions while reflecting engine characteristics. Overall, the proposed hybrid prediction model consistently exhibited higher predictive accuracy and lower error variance than the conventional bottom–up approaches for all pollutants.

To isolate the contribution of the hybrid architecture, a base learner (XGBoost) was compared against the stacked model under an identical protocol. For each pollutant, the same LASSO-selected features, identical train/test spilit, and tuning budgets were used. The meta-learner received the base predictions and their first differences, enabling it to reconcile sequence-level trends (from TSF-Transformer) with instantaneous nonlinear interactions (from XGBoost).

For CO2, relative to the XGBoost-only baseline, the stacked model reduced RMSE from 45.50 to 43.52 (\(\:\varDelta\:\)RMSE \(\:\approx\:\) 4.35%) and MAE from 38.29 to 35.75 (\(\:\varDelta\:\)MAE \(\:\approx\:\) 6.63%). Because R2 values were already saturated(\(\:\approx\:\)0.9935–0.9946), these absolute-error reductions are more indicative of practical gains, especially for inventory applications that penalize bias at higher loads.

In case of CO, the benefit of stacking was mixed. While the stacked model achieved slightly higher R2 than XGBoost-only, its RMSE was marginally worse (\(\:\approx\:\)+2% relative difference), with MAPE remaining similar. When target variance is dominated by unobserved combustion-specific factors, the marginal utility of combining learner becomes limited. In short, the hybrid model offers better calibration in some regimes but does no uniformly lower point error for CO given the current feature set.

For NOX, the stacked model improved over XGBoost-only, reducing RMSE from 1.70 to 1.60 (\(\:\varDelta\:\)RMSE \(\:\approx\:\) 5.9%) and MAE from 1.39 to 1.27 (\(\:\varDelta\:\)MAE \(\:\approx\:\) 8.6%), while maintaining competitive R2. These gains suggest that fusing short-horizon temporal cues (captured by TSF-Transformer) helps in regimes where formation chemistry interacts with engine load and temperature dynamics.

Stacking provided consistent, modest improvement for CO2 and NOx, where temporal structure and nonlinear interactions are complementary. For CO, the hybrid did not dominate the best single learner, indicating diminishing returns under heavy noise/omission (e.g., lack of fuel injection timing).

Although this study was validated on a single diesel engine vessel equipped with a CPP, the proposed hybrid framework (TSF-Transformer + XGBoost) was designed on the basis of time-series engine data acquired from the AMS rather than fuel-specific constants, suggesting its potential applicability to other vessel types. The engine data used in this work were collected under controlled condition together with emission measurements (HORIBA OBS-ONE-GS12) and are real time capable (0.1 Hz, 174 samples), thereby providing a realistic operational envelope for assessing scalability. With the recent introduction of alternative fuels in maritime sector (e.g., LNG, methanol, ammonia), applying this framework to new propulsion systems would require additional analysis of emission characteristics arising from combustion and re-training of the base framework. Because the proposed model learns the interactions between engine operating states and emission outputs rather than relying on fixed factor, it is expected to be sufficiently extensible. Furthermore, aside from CPP-affected segment, the operating relationship among RPM, load, and speed follows the propeller law, which was also observed in this study. SHAP-based sensitivity analysis indicated that the prediction results were not substantially influenced by pitch variations, thereby supporting the feasibility of extending the framework to vessels equipped with FPP.

text:
Singapore-based shipbuilder Strategic Marine has handed over a pair of low-emission catamaran ferries to the Government of Bermuda.

As disclosed in a social media post, the 40-meter-long newbuildings were delivered to the Bermudan government ahead of schedule. The vessels were designed by Australia’s One2Three Naval Architects.

The handover of the units, which will be able to carry around 550 passengers, marks the first collaboration between Bermuda and the Singaporean vessel construction player, according to officials from Strategic Marine. The parties reportedly shook hands on this project around two years ago.

The environmentally friendly catamarans, which are now ready for deployment in Bermudan waters, are described as having been built with features that would ensure operational efficiency as well as sustainable ferry services.

To be specific, as Strategic Marine has elaborated, the ferries were engineered to meet Bermuda’s current and future operational requirements, with projections that they could lead to a carbon dioxide (CO2) emission reduction level of at least 25%, particularly when compared to the already deployed units on a passenger-mile basis.

Reflecting on this development, Owen Darrell, JP, MP, Bermuda’s Minister of Tourism and Transport, Culture & Sport, remarked that the eco-conscious newbuilds could play a ‘significant’ role in supporting the country’s environmental goals and, at the same time, foster “long-term savings for the taxpayer”.

It is worth noting that Strategic Marine had been given the technical acceptance for the aluminium caramaran duo back in September this year, which marked the first step before the vessels’ handover and deployment.

Despite the trials and tribulations concerning global environmental regulations, particularly the International Maritime Organization’s (IMO) Net Zero Framework, which strives for climate neutrality by (or around 2050), Bermuda has kept pace with its sustainability targets. The territory’s vision is to minimize carbon emissions through a combination of energy and transport initiatives.

title: Emarat Maritime linked to newbuilding return with six-Aframax order at Hengli

Shipbroking and market sources indicate the owner has placed an order for six 115,000-dwt Aframax/LR2 tankers at Hengli Shipbuilding, with deliveries scheduled from 2027 onward.

On 18 November, Guangdong Songfa Ceramics disclosed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange that Hengli had secured a contract for six tankers of this size. The company did not reveal the owner’s identity, referring only to an “internationally renowned” shipping company.

According to the disclosure, the contract is valued between US$400M and US$600M, and the six vessels are slated for successive delivery throughout 2027.

In addition to the Aframax order, Hengli also reported a separate deal for two 306,000-dwt VLCCs from another unnamed “well-known European shipowner,” with a total value estimated between US$200M and US$300M.

Mixed fleet

Emarat Maritime currently manages a fleet of 19 vessels, according to information on its website. The company primarily focuses on the Aframax and Panamax segments, while also maintaining a footprint in the dry bulk market through its Ultramax and Supramax units.

The owner last ventured into newbuildings in 2023, when it ordered six Ultramaxes at Chinese yard New Dayang, all of which have since been delivered.

text:
Seventy projects are receiving over €600 million in EU grants to electrify and decarbonize road, maritime, inland waterway, and air transport along the trans-European transport network.

These projects will deploy alternative fuels supply infrastructure such as electric recharging stations, hydrogen refueling stations, electricity supply and ammonia and methanol bunkering facilities across 24 EU countries. Twenty-four maritime ports will benefit from the integration of greener technologies, including Onshore Power Supply (OPS), electrification of port services and ammonia bunkering facilities to fuel maritime vessels.

We are currently supporting 70 projects with €600 million in EU funding to accelerate the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure across Europe. These investments will strengthen our competitiveness and help make the transition to zero-emission mobility easier and more accessible for all citizens.

… said Commissioner for Sustainable Transport and Tourism Apostolos Tzitzikostas.

Europe’s transport network will be electrified through the installation of more than 1000 electric recharging points for light-duty vehicles with a capacity of 150 kW.

2000 new recharging points for heavy-duty vehicles will deliver a capacity of 350kW and 586 recharging points with a 1 MW power output. Additionally, 16 European airports will electrify their ground handling services, making a key contribution towards reducing aviation emissions.

The hydrogen economy will also be boosted through the installation of 38 hydrogen refueling stations for cars, trucks and buses.

This significant EU support for public and private organizations will accelerate the transport sector’s transition toward a sustainable future. With these new projects, more than €2.5 billion in EU grants has been allocated to alternative fuels projects through AFIF since 2021. This demonstrates EU’s ambition to make zero-emission mobility an everyday reality.

… commented Paloma Aba Garrote, Director of the European Climate, Infrastructure and Environment Executive Agency.

Next steps

Following the approval of the 70 selected projects by the EU Member States on 13 November 2025, the European Commission will adopt the award decision. The European Climate, Infrastructure and Environment Executive Agency (CINEA) is starting the preparation of the grant agreements with the successful projects.

text:
The ‘Net-Zero Guide: Practical Approaches for Global Shipping Companies’ provides a structured roadmap for advancing decarbonisation. Drawing on data-driven insights and real-world operator experience, the guide offers actionable steps for shipowners to align operational and investment decisions with both international and regional regulations. It also helps companies navigate uncertainties, adopt best practices, and take pragmatic actions that prepare them for future changes in a rapidly evolving landscape.

Knut Ørbeck-Nilssen, CEO, DNV Maritime said: “Shipping’s decarbonisation journey continues despite the postponement at the IMO. The reality is that energy efficiency and fuel flexibility or readiness are still considered and implemented on vessels. Continuing on this course will maintain competitiveness and contribute to the sector’s long-term decarbonisation goals. The collaboration with World Maritime Merchants Forum (WMMF) on this guide is itself a testament to the importance of working together to pave the way for successful decarbonization.”

Mr. Wang Yong Xin, the President of China Merchants Energy Shipping (CMES) said: “The Net-Zero Guide offers the industry a wealth of practical reference cases in a complex transition environment, helping shipping companies strike a balance between short-term operations and long-term emissions reduction.”

The guide addresses the increasing complexity and cost of compliance, especially for small and medium enterprises (SMEs), and outlines procedures to manage costs while supporting the transition of fleets toward net-zero emissions. It also sets out cost-effective actions, such as energy-efficiency upgrades, phased fuel transitions, and targeted fleet renewal or retrofits, to control expenses and avoid stranded assets. By aligning investments with operational improvements and market expectations, shipowners can strengthen their commercial resilience and position themselves for long-term success.

Shipowners are also urged to embed decarbonization into their core business strategies. This includes linking compliance with fleet investment and financing, while adopting a lifecycle approach to fleet management that balances renewal, retrofits, and operational optimisation. Structured competence development and robust change management are essential to building organizational capability and supporting sustainable growth. By leveraging partnerships across the value chain and investing in digitalisation and data governance, companies can enhance transparency, ensure regulatory compliance, and unlock long-term efficiencies.

text:
The Dutch container terminal operator APM Terminals, a part of Denmark’s shipping giant A.P. Moller – Maersk, has signed a concession agreement valued at $550 million with the Bangladeshi Chittagong Port Authority (CPA), aiming to deepen the South Asian nation’s infrastructural development and sustainability efforts.

The 30-year concession agreement, reportedly one of the largest public-private partnership (PPP) investments in Bangladesh’s history, concerns the development of the Laldia Container Terminal in Chattogram. The initiative will also be joined by local partner QNS Container Services.

The Laldia Container Terminal is to be fully designed, funded, constructed and operated by the investors, which is said to be a “first-of-its-kind” model for the country’s port infrastructure.

More importantly, according to officials from APM Terminals, the project is part of the Sustainable Green Framework Engagement between Denmark and Bangladesh, a bilateral collaboration that seeks to pave the way for green investment, sustainable economic relations and job creation.

“The Laldia Container Terminal demonstrates Bangladesh’s commitment to reform, transparency and investment-friendly growth. Laldia will be the country’s first green port and the single largest European foreign direct investment in Bangladesh,” Chief Adviser of the Government of Bangladesh, Muhammad Yunus, commented.

“Bangladesh is one of the fastest-growing economies of the world, and with the graduation from LDC just around the corner, it’s an ideal time for Bangladesh to experience the reduced cost of trade from cutting-edge technology and best practices of an ‘international standard’ terminal operator,” Nurul Qayyum Khan, Chairman of QNS Container Services, further remarked.

As highlighted, the agreement will strive to build what is described as “one of South Asia’s first energy-efficient, low-emission terminals”, aligned with net-zero targets and envisaged to support Bangladesh’s long-term climate goals.

Key features of the project are set to entail electrified cargo-handling equipment, solar power installations on terminal structures, and shore power-ready systems allowing ships to plug into the grid. These measures are expected to slash greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions as well as noise and air pollution and thus, benefit not just the environment but also the workforce and the nearby communities.

Once operational (approximately in 2030), the terminal is anticipated to expand Bangladesh’s annual port handling capacity by over 800,000 TEUs, which could ‘improve’ the country’s global trade efficiency and connectivity.

Moreover, as disclosed, the new deep-water facility will allow the Port of Chattogram to handle vessels potentially up to 6,000 TEUs over time, whilst it can handle those of just up to 2,800 TEUs at the present moment.

In terms of its sustainability efforts, Bangladesh has had its peaks and valleys over the years, especially in the maritime transport industry, the world’s main trade artery.

In April 2025, the country received around $650 million from the World Bank to develop the Bay Terminal Marine Infrastructure Project in Chittagong to ‘modernize’ the port’s facilities. The effort encompasses the construction of a ‘climate-resilient’ breakwater and access channel to fit larger vessels, per Reuters.

text:
Japanese shipping firm NYK Group says ammonia bunkers will be its primary fuel to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

It sees the use of ammonia-powered vessels starting this year and growing streadily through 2050 and beyond.

In that time, use of LNG and LPG-powered vessels peaks around 2035 with that tonnage transitioning to ammonia.

Methanol also still has a place in NYK's plans, albeit playing a smaller role than that of ammonia, with uptake starting around 2030 and growing steadily through 2050 and beyond.

The plans were laid out Monday by Takaya Soga, president and CEO of NYK, in his opening address at the World Maritime Merchants Forum 2025, where Ship & Bunker was in attendance as part of Hong Kong Maritime Week 2025.

The choice of ammonia as NYK's principal route to net zero is notable.

Both LNG and methanol are widely seen as the main alternatives to traditional oil bunkers and continue to receive significantly more backing from the industry with only five ammonia vessels ordered so far this year, compared to 147 powered by LNG and 47 by methanol.

"The development and introduction of ammonia-fuelled vessels is positioned as our main scenario," Soga said at the event, adding that the company is already gaining ammonia expertise by operating its ammonia-fuelled tugboat, Sakuyake.

The Sakuyake had completed a three-month demonstration voyage in March 2025, during which it achieved a GHG emission reduction of up to 95%.

Soga noted that ammonia is recognized for its ability to produce zero harmful emissions, making it a key solution for decarbonization in the shipping industry, but left unsaid was the widely-held concerns over the toxicity of ammonia, a factor considered by many as its main drawback when compared to methanol and LNG.

Still, Soga did note that NYK is advancing its ability to handle ammonia safety and highlighted the ship-to-ship ammonia cargo transfer that took place between the NYK-owned ammonia carrier Berlian Ekuator and Eco Enchanted off Spain in September 2025.

"This achievement demonstrates the safety and the practicality of large-scale ammonia transportation," Soga said.

Despite progress, Soga argued that the main challenge remains the high cost of green ammonia.

"So the foundation for using ammonia as a marine fuel is in place, but the main barrier right now is cost," Soga said.

"Green ammonia, specifically blue or green ammonia, is still much more expensive than traditional options.

"On the other hand, currently, numerous grey ammonia plants exist globally."

Soga sees these grey ammonia plants to play a foundational role in the development of blue and green ammonia plants in the future.

"To overcome the cost of the barrier, we need to accelerate clean ammonia development to enable mass production and drive down costs," he concluded.

text:
October brought both turbulent policy development and tangible progress for the European hydrogen market. In this edition of Hydrogen Compass, we explore how delayed international frameworks, recalibrated national strategies, and new legislative moves reveal a region still defining its hydrogen future. However, as governments debate the path forwards, developers are pressing ahead, moving projects from planning to execution and signalling that Europe’s hydrogen market is still taking shape.

The next edition will be published in December. In the meantime, if you have any comments or feedback, please do reach out to Jun Sasamura (jsasamura@westwoodenergy.com).

Project developments press ahead

Across Europe, developers pressed ahead with major projects. From refinery decarbonisation in Portugal and large-scale e-fuel initiatives in Spain, to new electrolysis plants in Germany and the UK, investment continued and key milestones were reached. This momentum reflects the relative resilience of the industry, even as regulatory and commercial challenges persist. Against this backdrop of positive progress, it is important to acknowledge that policy uncertainty is ongoing, shaping the pace and structure of future developments overall.

Policy turbulence across Europe

Policy delays and uncertainty have continued to define the pace of the European hydrogen market and October was no exception. While the EU advanced key regulatory frameworks, national governments took divergent paths. Meanwhile, international developments, particularly in maritime regulation, added further complexity.

IMO delays net-zero framework

The International Maritime Organisation (IMO) voted in October to delay its Net-Zero Framework (NZF) by one year. This delay could significantly impact future demand for hydrogen and green ammonia in the maritime sector. Originally designed to accelerate the uptake of renewable and low-carbon fuels, the NZF’s postponement introduces further uncertainty for developers and investors.

The delays followed intense opposition from the US, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Russia. The US president publicly condemned the NZF, calling it a ‘Global Green New Scam Tax on Shipping’ and reportedly threatened visa restrictions and higher trade costs for countries supporting the framework.

IMO Secretary General Aresenio Dominguez and International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) Secretary General Thomas Kazakos both expressed disappointments, calling the outcome a setback for zero-carbon shipping and investment in green fuels.

With the NZF now on hold, demand forecasts for hydrogen-derived marine fuels are likely to be revised downward, potentially slowing investment in hydrogen supply projects and green ammonia production capacity.

Diverging national strategies in Europe

While the EU continues to refine its hydrogen policy framework, national governments are taking varied approaches, with some accelerating and others reassessing.

EU: The European Parliament approved the EU’s Delegated Act on low-carbon hydrogen in October. The Act, originally adopted by the Commission in July, sets a 70% emissions reduction threshold for low-carbon hydrogen compared to fossil fuels.

It aims to provide clarity on CCS-enabled hydrogen and non-renewable-powered electrolysis and allows such project to access funding under the European Hydrogen Bank. Commissioner Dan Jørgensen confirmed that projects making investment decisions now won’t be subject to future revisions of the Act, which creates an important reassurance for developers.

By expanding eligibility and establishing clear emissions criteria, the Delegated Act is expected to strengthen investor confidence and maintain momentum in Europe’s hydrogen market, particularly as the sector seeks greater flexibility in production pathways.

Portugal: Portugal’s Secretary of State for Energy, João Barroca, criticised the previous government’s heavy focus on renewable hydrogen last month, calling it a misguided priority that diverted resources from more practical decarbonisation options like biomethane. He warned that an export-driven hydrogen strategy has failed to create domestic value or support Portuguese industry.

Reflecting this change in direction, the government revised its electrolyser capacity target down from the previous administration’s 5.5GW target to 3GW in the October 2024 climate plan. Despite this recalibration, Portugal has continued to progress key infrastructure projects, including a 10% hydrogen blending trial in the gas grid and the CelZa pipeline linking to Spain as part of the H2Med corridor.

This more pragmatic stance signals a strategic pivot, focused on aligning hydrogen policy with domestic industrial needs and long-term economic resilience.

Finland: In October, the Finnish government announced plans to finalise its dedicated hydrogen law by the end of 2025, with implementation scheduled for 2026. The legislation will clarify rules for production, transmission, ownership, pricing and safety, replacing the current reliance on natural gas regulations.

State-owned Gasgrid is already progressing with the national hydrogen network and the 2,500km Nordic-Baltic Hydrogen Corridor. Environmental assessments have also begun, with Worley appointed to lead front-end engineering through 2028.

Finland’s proactive approach aims to provide greater regulatory certainty, supporting its position as a key player in Northern Europe.

Germany: Germany’s hydrogen strategy came under scrutiny in October following a report from the federal audit office, which called for a revision to safeguard both climate and economic goals. The report criticised slow progress towards the country’s 10GW (6.6 GW(LHV)) 2030 target and flagged financial risks associated with the planned 9,000km hydrogen core network.

Despite these concerns, the German government advanced several key measures last month. The federal cabinet approved the draft Hydrogen Acceleration Act, which aims to streamline permitting for hydrogen production, imports, storage, and infrastructure. The law will designate hydrogen projects as being of ‘overriding public interest,’ giving them priority in planning and legal processes. Amendments to the Federal Mining Act will also permit natural hydrogen exploration in the country.

Germany also plans to review and potentially overhaul its renewable hydrogen support framework. The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWK) acknowledged that the market has underperformed, prompting a review of funding schemes and a shift toward imports and cost-efficiency. Current programmes include €2.6 billion for H2Global import auctions, €4.6 billion for the Hy2Infra network, €30 million per project for overseas hydrogen investments, and a €6 billion Carbon Contracts for Difference (CCfD) to support industrial decarbonisation, which opened for applications for its second round in October.

Looking ahead, policy is expected to focus on reducing system costs by optimising electrolyser siting and utilising excess renewable power. Germany also plans to open capacity reservations for its hydrogen core network in 2026, a key enabler for market activation. The country’s hydrogen policy is shifting towards ensuring execution, focusing on cost discipline, infrastructure readiness, and streamlined governance to restore investor confidence.

text:
There seems to have been a recent surge of interest in nuclear power afloat. Most of this is coming from the major classification societies – all have recently published studies which confirm the viability of nuclear as an emission-free power source. And shipbuilders and designers are starting to come up with firm proposals.

It is tempting to speculate on why this might be. After all, the focus has been on using future fuels like ammonia, methanol or hydrogen, with ‘bridging’ fuels like LNG and bio-diesel being promoted to fill the gap between realisation on the need to cut emissions – both quickly and significantly – and the alternative fuels becoming available.

It’s true to say that the green revolution has - temporarily we hope - stalled. Some of this feeling is no doubt down to the still-unanswered questions of when, and how, supplies of future fuels will be available in the quantities, and at affordable cost, to satisfy the considerable demands of the world’s shipping fleet alongside other hard-to-abate industries. And if we look at the ‘green’ versions of these fuels, produced using solely renewable energy, the goal looks even more ambitious. Then there are the concerns over safety and toxicity of these fuels that still have to be overcome.

Hong Kong’s Secretary for Transport and Logistics Ms Mable Chan on Monday (17 November) said the city ranked seventh globally in bunkering, second in China and first in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area.

Since the first LNG bunkering operation in February this year, she said over 200 000 metric tonnes (mt) of biodiesel and LNG have been bunkered in Hong Kong, involving a total of 13 LNG bunkering operations.

Classification society DNV and the World Maritime Merchants Forum (WMMF) ESG team on Monday (17 November) published a new guide to help shipowners navigate evolving challenges, an effort supported by industry organizations in Hong Kong and worldwide.

The Net-Zero Guide: Practical Approaches for Global Shipping Companies provides a structured roadmap for advancing decarbonization. Drawing on data-driven insights and real-world operator experience, the guide offers actionable steps for shipowners to align operational and investment decisions with both international and regional regulations.

It also helps companies navigate uncertainties, adopt best practices, and take pragmatic actions that prepare them for future changes in a rapidly evolving landscape.

Marine fuel supplier Peninsula on Monday (17 November) announced the expansion of its strategic infrastructure at the Port of Rotterdam with the opening of a new storage and blending facility at Chane Terminal.

The first phase is now live with Peninsula’s Chane Terminal featuring nine new tanks dedicated to biofuel blending and storage, with a total capacity of 30,000 cubic metres. The facility is ISCC certified and Nea registered, ensuring full compliance and traceability for all operations.

Enhanced infrastructure includes three jetties and seven berths for barges up to 135 metres, plus a jetty for seagoing vessels, supporting efficient logistics and inter-terminal transfers (ITT) with major oil companies.

“This expansion strengthens Peninsula’s operational capabilities in the ARA region and reinforces its role as a key player in supporting Europe’s energy transition,” the company said on its website.

Peninsula’s new setup allows for the blending of any biofuel grade (HSFO/VLSFO), from B5 to B100, with full control over the blending process and product quality. The facility’s flexibility enables Peninsula to blend products to preferred ratios, enhancing both quality and customer choice.

The company added the Chane Terminal will play a pivotal role in advancing Peninsula’s biofuel strategy, supporting decarbonisation efforts and delivering value to customers throughout Europe.

Thomas Van Hoeteghem, Regional Supply Manager North-West Europe at Peninsula, said: “We are delighted to expand our footprint in Rotterdam, Europe’s largest port. title: SAMUEL PETERSON: Human Prosperity, Carbon Taxes, And The UN – IJR
description:
Proponents of carbon taxes generally argue that since climate change is an existential threat to human existence, drastic measures must be taken in all aspects of our lives to address the projected costs.
In the political arena, they should vote out so-called “climate deniers.” In the economic sphere, carbon taxes are offered as a technocratic quick fix to carbon emissions.
Carbon taxes are not a matter of scientific fact.
In the case of carbon taxes, the time horizon selected plays a major role in the outcome.
Carbon taxes, if sufficiently high, can prevent or significantly delay these processes, thereby undermining their supposed purpose.
text:
Unelected regulators and bureaucrats from the United Nations have pushed for crushing the global economy in the name of saving the planet.

In October, the International Maritime Organization (IMO), a specialized agency within the U.N., proposed a carbon tax in order to slash the emissions of shipping vessels. This comes after the IMO’s April 2025 decision to adopt net-zero standards for global shipping.

Had the IMO agreed to the regulation, it would have been the first global tax on greenhouse gas emissions. Thankfully, the United States was able to effectively shut down those proposals; however, while these regulations have been temporarily halted, the erroneous ideas behind them continue to grow in support.

Proponents of carbon taxes generally argue that since climate change is an existential threat to human existence, drastic measures must be taken in all aspects of our lives to address the projected costs. People should eat less meat and use public transportation more often. In the political arena, they should vote out so-called “climate deniers.” In the economic sphere, carbon taxes are offered as a technocratic quick fix to carbon emissions. Is any of this worth it? Or are the benefits greater than the costs? In the case of climate change, the answer is no.

Carbon taxes are not a matter of scientific fact. As with all models, the assumptions drive the analysis. In the case of carbon taxes, the time horizon selected plays a major role in the outcome. So, too, does the discount rate and the specific integrated assessment models.

In other words, “Two economists can give vastly different estimates of the social cost of carbon, even if they agree on the objective facts underlying the analysis.” If the assumptions are subjective, as they are in carbon taxes, then they are not scientific facts. As I’ve pointed out, “carbon pricing models are as much political constructs as they are economic tools.” One must also ask whether carbon taxes will remain unchanged or gradually increase over time to advance other political agendas. In this proposal, the answer is that it increases over time.

Additionally, since these models are driven by assumptions, one would be right in asking who gets to impose these taxes? Of course, those would be the unelected bureaucrats at the IMO. No American who would be subject to these taxes ever voted for the people attempting to create the “world’s first global carbon tax.” It brings to mind the phrase “no taxation without representation.”

In an ironic twist, imposing carbon taxes on global shipping might actually be one of the worst ways to slash emissions, given the enormous gains from trade. Simply put, trade makes the world grow rich. Not just wealthy nations like those in the West, but every nation, even the most poor, grows richer. In wealthy countries, trade can help address climate change by enabling adaptation and innovation. For poorer countries, material gains from trade can help prevent their populations from starving and also help them advance along the environmental Kuznets curve.

In other words, the advantages of trade can, over time, make a country go from being so poor that a high level of air pollution is necessary for its survival to being rich enough to afford reducing or eliminating pollution. Carbon taxes, if sufficiently high, can prevent or significantly delay these processes, thereby undermining their supposed purpose. Not to mention, as of today, maritime shipping accounts for only about 3% of total global emissions.

The same ingenuity that brought us modern shipping will continue to power the global economy and fund growth and innovation, if we let it. The world does not need a layer of global bureaucracy for the sake of virtue signaling. What it needs is an understanding of both economics and human progress.

History shows that prosperity, innovation, and free trade are what make societies cleaner, healthier, and richer. Our choice is not between saving the planet and saving the economy; it is between free societies and free markets or surrendering responsibility to unelected international regulators and busybodies. The former has lifted billions out of poverty, and the latter threatens to drag us all backwards.

Samuel Peterson is a Research Fellow at the Institute for Energy Research.

text:
Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines hosted a pivotal roundtable discussion aboard the Borealis on 12th November 2025, inviting UK government officials and energy sector leaders to explore the future of the cruise industry in a low-carbon world. The event, held at Portsmouth International Port Cruise Terminal, provided a platform for key stakeholders to delve into the critical steps needed to achieve net zero emissions in the cruise sector.

The gathering, facilitated by the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA), united experts from across various sectors, including the Energy Networks Association, Ofgem, the National Energy System Operator, and officials from the Department for Transport and the Department for Energy Security & Net Zero. The roundtable was part of an ongoing dialogue aimed at identifying actionable solutions to accelerate the cruise industry’s shift towards sustainable practices.

A Collaborative Approach to Decarbonizing the Cruise Sector

The roundtable centred on the cruise industry’s ambitious net zero target by 2050, in line with the International Maritime Organization’s (IMO) 2023 strategy to cut greenhouse gas emissions from maritime vessels. CLIA, which led the discussions, emphasized the importance of cross-industry collaboration in shaping a sustainable future for cruising.

A major focus was the industry’s transition to cleaner energy, specifically the role of Onshore Power Supply (OPS) systems. OPS technology enables cruise ships to draw electricity directly from the shore grid while docked, thus eliminating the need for onboard diesel generators and significantly reducing emissions while at port.

Portsmouth’s Role in the Green Transition

One of the most significant initiatives highlighted was the installation of OPS at Portsmouth, where a new system is being rolled out. The project is expected to reduce carbon emissions by an estimated 20,000 metric tonnes annually starting in 2027. This effort aligns with the UK’s broader decarbonisation goals and marks a key milestone in advancing sustainable energy solutions for the cruise industry.

The roundtable discussions underscored that transitioning to OPS and other clean technologies is vital for reducing the environmental impact of the cruise sector. As the industry embraces innovative energy solutions, the partnership between government, energy stakeholders, and cruise operators will play a central role in meeting the ambitious sustainability targets set for the coming decades.

The collaboration fostered at Portsmouth reflects the shared commitment to reducing the cruise industry’s carbon footprint and further establishes the UK as a leader in green maritime technology.

Mike Sellers, Director at Portsmouth International Port, commented: “It’s evident there is a real appetite for sustainable fuel technology. While delivering this innovative system is not without its challenges, it was great to know that there’s a support and willingness for this to be a success.”

Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines has pledged to incorporate Onshore Power Supply (OPS) on its sister ships, Borealis and Bolette, wherever possible, while continuing to invest in low-carbon technologies aimed at shaping a more sustainable cruising future. Recent enhancements to the vessels include the application of silicone-based hull coatings and the installation of advanced propeller systems, both designed to improve hydrodynamic efficiency and optimize fuel performance.

During the event, attendees were also given the exclusive chance to explore behind the scenes aboard the Borealis, with guided tours that included the Engine Control Room, Shore Power Room, Recycling Centre, and the Bridge. These tours offered valuable insight into the cruise line’s operations and the sustainability initiatives being adopted to reduce its environmental footprint.

Samantha Stimpson, CEO of Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines, said: “We are proud to have hosted this important discussion aboard Borealis and help shape the cruise industry’s path toward net zero emissions. Achieving net zero by 2050 is ambitious, which makes events like this vital for identifying practical strategies and collaborative solutions.

“For us, sustainability is more than a goal – it’s a responsibility. By adopting solutions such as shore power and working hand in hand with government and industry partners, we can make meaningful progress in reducing our impact and protecting the oceans we sail and the destinations we’re privileged to visit.”

Andy Harmer OBE, Managing Director of CLIA UK & Ireland, added: “The Roundtable hosted onboard Borealis was a great opportunity to discuss the importance of Onshore Power Supply which is a crucial component of our industry’s decarbonisation journey. Over 50% of the global cruise fleet is already able to plug in, allowing ships to turn off their engines for emissions reductions of up to 98%.

“CLIA has a vital role in bringing industry together with Governments, raising the importance of environmental technologies and practices so that we can work together in our pursuit of net zero emissions by 2050.”

The event highlighted the crucial role of collaboration between cruise lines, ports, and government bodies in reaching decarbonisation goals and the overarching target of achieving net zero emissions. Industry-wide, operators are implementing strategies like Onshore Power Supply (OPS), alternative fuels, and energy-efficient technologies to drive faster progress towards these objectives.

Fred. Olsen Cruise Lines continues to prioritize reducing its environmental footprint and remains dedicated to advancing a more sustainable cruise industry for future generations.

text:
Japanese shipping firm NYK Group sees ammonia-fuelled ships to be the core of its plans to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

The company is already gaining ammonia expertise by operating its ammonia-fuelled tugboat -Sakuyake, Takaya Soga, president and CEO of NYK, said at the opening of Hong Kong Maritime Week 2025 on Monday.

"The development and introduction of ammonia-fuelled vessels is positioned as our main scenario," Soga said at the event.

"We see ammonia as a core next-generation marine fuel."

The firm has previously talked of other alternative marine fuels including methanol and LNG as being under consideration for its decarbonisation plans.

The Sakuyake had completed a three-month demonstration voyage in March 2025, during which it achieved a GHG emission reduction of up to 95%.

Ammonia is recognized for its ability to produce zero harmful emissions, making it a key solution for decarbonization in the shipping industry, he said.

Soga said that NYK is also advancing operational expertise to handle ammonia safety.

He highlighted the ship-to-ship ammonia cargo transfer that took place between the NYK-owned ammonia carrier Berlian Ekuator and Eco Enchanted off Spain in September 2025.

"This achievement demonstrates the safety and the practicality of large-scale ammonia transportation," Soga said.

Despite progress, Soga argued that the main challenge remains the high cost of green ammonia.

"So the foundation for using ammonia as a marine fuel is in place, but the main barrier right now is cost," Soga said.

"Green ammonia, specifically blue or green ammonia, is still much more expensive than traditional options.

"On the other hand, currently, numerous grey ammonia plants exist globally."

Soga sees these grey ammonia plants to play a foundational role in the development of blue and green ammonia plants in the future.

"To overcome the cost of the barrier, we need to accelerate clean ammonia development to enable mass production and drive down costs," he concluded.

Addressing the opening ceremony on 17 November, Chief Executive John Lee highlighted the challenges of geopolitical discord, technological disruption and climate change. Complementing this, the theme of the World Maritime Merchants Forum, “Steering Sustainability Through Changes,” serves as a navigational chart for the journey ahead. Together, the themes aim to serve as a warning and a call for coordinated action.

In a world being reshaped by geopolitical discord, technological disruption and climate change, these themes are more than aspirational. They sound an alarm, a wake-up call to collective action.

…said John Lee.

According to the Chief Executive, in this era of profound and complex transformation, Hong Kong’s role as a stable, reliable and dynamic maritime hub has never been more vital. The principle of “one country, two systems” remains the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s success, providing a foundation for continued development.

As the nation’s only bilingual common law jurisdiction, Hong Kong offers a simple and low tax regime, free-port status and the unfettered flow of capital, information and talent.

text:
Fresh from rubbishing LNG at Nor-Shipping in June, speaking at COP30 Fortescue Chairman Andrew Forrest called for the maritime sector to “expose the thugs” that used “gangster tactics” to delay the IMO’s net zero framework (NZF).

The IMO’s Marine Environment Protection Committee met in a special session in October to approve the NZF that laid a pathway to net zero shipping by 2050, and which was finally agreed in April this year.

Prior to the October Extraordinary Session at the IMO US officials aided by Saudi Arabian representatives had made efforts to scupper the NZF in its entirety, threatening nation states with reprisals if they voted for the regulations.

IMO Secretary General Arsenio Dominguez remained upbeat believing that the NZF would be passed, but ultimately it was agreed to delay its implementation by a year.

In a panel discussion organised by the IMO’s head of climate action Roel Hoenders and moderated by Lloyd’s Register’s Katherine Palmer, at COP30, an audience member asked, “how we will prevent another debacle at the following MEPC-ES2?”

Andrew Forrest responded: “The IMO did not fail. Thugs who, knowing that they had lost on the inside, reverted to gangster tactics outside the building, threatening countries and individuals.”

According to Forrest the solution to defeating these subversives was transparency.

“Expose the thugs. If we let the world know what they're doing as they're doing it, they will lose their power.”

He added that he and others would do what they could to indemnify those under threat.

Australian miner Fortescue has thrown its weight behind green ammonia as the way forward to decarbonise shipping and transport operations.

The maritime industry, however, remains divided with those closer to consumers, such as container ship operators, generally for a global regulation and those that operate general cargo vessels, such as tankers and bulk operators against.

The World Shipping Council along with the International Chamber of Shipping and three other industry bodies released a statement shortly after the Extraordinary Meeting in October backing the IMO.

“Only global rules will decarbonise a global industry. Without the Framework, shipping would risk a growing patchwork of unilateral regulations, increasing costs without effectively contributing to decarbonisation,” said the letter.

Meanwhile, speaking at October’s Cyprus Maritime conference Greek shipping magnate George Procopiou told the audience: “It is the first time that shipowners and environmentalists are aligned, all of us want less pollution. But he added, no green fuels are available. “If there is a good quality fuel that makes less emissions, tell us where to buy it.”

Madadh MacLaine, the Secretary-Generalat Zero Emission Ship Technology Association told Seatrade Maritime News: "Shipping needs to accept the fact that we cannot continue to pollute the ocean. We've crossed the planetary boundary for ocean acidification, and yet shipping continues the fantasy of using so called “ZNZ” fuels that release CO2 and other toxins into the atmosphere and marine environment.”

MacLaine added: “The ocean is the Earth's regulatory system, covering more than 70% of its surface. Shipping views it as a means for trade, but over 3 billion people rely on it for food—and all of us rely on it for oxygen. At what point will shipping wake up to the fact that we can and must ‘Do No Harm’? [As evidenced by the ShipZERO30 report]”

text:
EnviTec Biogas and TT-Line have signed a contract to supply bio-LNG to the ferry operator, following a trial delivery of 40 tonnes to TT-Line’s Peter Pan vessel.

“Supplying renewable bio-LNG to TT-Line’s ferries allows us to contribute to lower emissions in shipping,” said Markus Pille, Managing Director of EnviTec Energy.

The move comes in response to the EU’s FuelEU Maritime regulation, which sets mandatory limits on the greenhouse gas intensity of fuels used on ships over 5,000 gross tonnes in commercial passenger or freight service.

The rules remain in effect while the International Maritime Organization (IMO) has delayed its decision on a global “Net Zero Framework,” which would have introduced a CO₂ pricing system and a pathway for shipping to reach climate neutrality by 2050.

Torben Nikolay, CFO of TT-Line, noted that Peter Pan and her sister ship Nils Holgersson are the largest LNG-powered Ro-Pax ferries worldwide.

“These ships go beyond simply meeting regulatory requirements. We aim to prepare our fleet for a more sustainable future. Earlier this year, we carried out several bio-LNG deliveries by bunker barge, and this agreement with EnviTec allows us to refuel by truck as well,” he said.

TT-Line operates routes connecting German Baltic ports at Travemünde and Rostock with Świnoujście in Poland and Klaipėda in Lithuania, as well as southern Swedish ports including Trelleborg and Karlshamn.

Annually, the company transports about one million passengers, 250,000 cars and roughly 500,000 freight units, making it the main operator on southern Sweden routes.

EnviTec Biogas produces bio-LNG from organic waste such as slurry, poultry manure, food waste and agricultural residues.

The process involves converting biomass into biogas, upgrading it to biomethane using EnviThan technology, and then liquefying it.

Some of the bio-LNG is sourced from the company’s BioEnergie Park in Güstrow, Germany, the country’s largest integrated bio-LNG facility.

According to EnviTec, the bio-LNG can cut emissions by up to 100% compared with marine diesel, helping shipping companies meet the FuelEU Maritime regulation targets.
